description:
Drosophila willistoni is a species of fruit fly that belongs to the genus Drosophila. It is a member of the Drosophila willistoni species group, which is part of the subgenus Sophophora.

Drosophila willistoni is a small insect, typically measuring around 2-3 millimeters in length. It has a yellowish-brown body with a darker abdomen and reddish-brown eyes. The wings are transparent and clear, with a characteristic dark spot near the tip.

This species is widely distributed in the tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas, including South America, Central America, and the Caribbean islands. It is commonly found in forest habitats, where it feeds on the rotting fruit and fungi that are its primary food sources.

Drosophila willistoni is an important model organism in the field of genetics and evolutionary biology. It has been extensively studied for its genetic diversity, chromosomal structure, and adaptation to different environments. The species has been used to investigate topics such as population genetics, speciation, and the evolution of reproductive isolation.

Overall, Drosophila willistoni is a well-known and widely studied fruit fly species that has contributed significantly to our understanding of the genetic and evolutionary processes in insects.
